   Glucose
   100
   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:14.7/34.6/1.3, Lactic Acid:1.3 mmol/L,
   Ca++:7.2 mg/dL (ALB 1.7), Mg++:2.4 mg/dL, PO4:2.2 mg/dL
   Microbiology: Blood Cx - GPCs in pairs and long chains ([**12-26**])
   Urine Cx - mixed bacterial flora c/w contamination
   C.diff negative x1
   Abscess - 3+ PMNs, 4+ GNRs, 4+ GPCs in pairs and short chains
   Assessment and Plan
 SEPSIS WITHOUT ORGAN DYSFUNCTION
 DECUBITUS ULCER (PRESENT AT ADMISSION)
 PAIN CONTROL (ACUTE PAIN, CHRONIC PAIN)
 ALTERATION IN NUTRITION
   58-yo paraplegic man with decubitus ulcers with Vac drains, colostomy /
   urostomy, who presents with fever, tachycardia, and hypotension, c/w
   sepsis.
   #. Septic shock - Pt w/ fever, leukocytosis and bandemia, all
   supportive of current infection. VS abnormalities c/w septic shock. Pt
   mentating appropriately and currently w/o signs of end-organ damage.
   Infectious source not yet obvious, possibilities includes urine
   (although may be colonized given suprapubic catheter), decubitus ulcers
   (although do not appear infected on exam), pulmonary (given his
   symptoms, although CXR was clear), abdominal (given his tender abdomen,
   although no findings on CT) and right anterior thigh fluid collection.
   Most likely source is right hip/groin abscess given findings from IR
   tap, concern for joint involvement and hardware involvement. C.diff
   negative, Urine Cx neg. Blood Cx +GPCs [**12-26**].
   - cont aggressive IVF resuscitation w/ NS
   - cont vasopressor support until adequately fluid resuscitated
   - cont broad spectrum Abx: Vanc / Zosyn / Azithro pending Cx data
   - f/u blood culture, fluid aspirate, send surveillance blood cultures
   - appreciate general surgery and orthopedics consults, will need
   probable surgical intervention given findings and location
   - follow serial labs including lactate, chemistries, blood gases
   #. Right anterior groin collection - S/p attempted aspiration in ED,
   fluid sent for analysis. Fluid showing probable poly-microbial
   collection.
   - appreciate general surgery and orthopedics consults, will need
   probable surgical intervention given findings and location
   - cont broad spectrum Abx: Vanc / Zosyn / Azithro pending Cx data
   #. Decubitus ulcerations - Chronic, currently w/ wound-Vacs in place on
   two separate ulcers.
   - wound care nursing consult
   - contine to monitor for signs of infection
   - would likely be adequately covered with broad-spectrums
   #. Productive cough - Symptoms are likely upper respiratory in origin,
   and clear exam and CXR is consistent. However, given his hypovolemia
   from sepsis, a pneumonia may be missed.
   - consider CXR after adequate IVF resuscitation
   - cont home Albuterol nebs PRN
   - pneumonia would be adequately covered with broad-spectrums
   #. Abdominal pain - Chronic per patient, and symptoms are migratory in
   nature. CT with chronic findings, no acute changes.
   - appreciate general surgery recs
   - cont to monitor
   #. Paraplegia
   - cont Lovenox, holding this morning for aspiration procedure
   - cont home OxyContin, PRN Percocet / Tylenol, Ativan
   - cont home vitamins: Vit B12, iron, folate, MVI
   - cont home bowel regimen: Colace, PRN Senna / Bisacodyl / MoM
   - Nutrition consult
   #. GERD - cont home PPI, PRN antacid
   #. HL - cont home TriCor
   #. Communication - with patient, girlfriend [**Name (NI) 7158**] [**Name (NI) 7159**]
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7160**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for procedure, o/w Regular diet, nutrition c/s,
   aggressive IVF resuscitation, replete lytes PRN
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2105-4-20**] 06:52 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Lovenox
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU

Do not echo my prompt. Please do not remind me what I asked you for. Do not apologize. Do not self-reference. Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic man with decubitus ulcers, colostomy/urostomy, and a history of chronic pain. He was admitted with fever, tachycardia, and hypotension, consistent with sepsis. The patient has been diagnosed with sepsis without organ dysfunction, and the infectious source is not yet clear. Possible sources include urine, decubitus ulcers, pulmonary, abdominal, and right anterior thigh fluid collection.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Temperature 35.3째C, heart rate 61 bpm, blood pressure 109/60 mmHg, respiratory rate 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 99%.
* Physical examination: General condition is comfortable, with sclera anicteric, dry mucous membranes, and clear lungs. The patient has multiple sacral decubitus ulcers, bilateral ankle ulcers, and mild bilateral lower extremity edema.
* Laboratory results: White blood cell count 19.3 K/uL, hemoglobin 8.1 g/dL, platelet count 546 K/uL, creatinine 0.5 mg/dL, glucose 100 mg/dL, and lactate 1.3 mmol/L.
* Imaging studies: Chest X-ray was clear, and computed tomography (CT) scan showed chronic findings with no acute changes.

The patient is receiving aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation, vasopressor support, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. He is also being treated for pain, nausea, and vomiting.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Septic shock: The patient's hypotension and tachycardia are consistent with septic shock, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis can lead to organ dysfunction, including renal, hepatic, and respiratory failure.
3. Decubitus ulcer infection: The patient's decubitus ulcers are at risk of becoming infected, which can lead to further complications and prolonged hospitalization.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's hypovolemia from sepsis may mask symptoms of pneumonia, which can lead to delayed diagnosis and treatment.
5. Abdominal abscess: The patient's abdominal pain and tenderness may indicate an abdominal abscess, which can lead to further complications and surgical intervention.
6. Hardware infection: The patient's hardware (e.g., colostomy/urostomy) may be infected, which can lead to further complications and surgical intervention.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's paraplegia and chronic pain may lead to nutritional deficiencies, which can exacerbate his condition and increase the risk of complications.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation, vasopressor support, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. The patient should also be monitored closely for signs of organ dysfunction and infection, and surgical intervention should be considered for the right anterior groin collection and potential abdominal abscess.

The patient has a complex medical history, including chronic pain, paraplegia, and chronic per patient abdominal pain.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 37째C (98.6째F), HR 61 bpm, BP 109/60 mmHg, RR 13 inspirations per minute, SpO2 99%.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 10 mmHg, MAP 75 mmHg, and vasopressor support is required.
* Fluid balance: Total input 9,049 mL, total output 2,295 mL, with a positive balance of 6,754 mL.
* Respiratory support: O2 delivery device none, SpO2 99%, and ABG: pH 7.21, PCO2 45 mmHg, PO2 110 mmHg.
* Laboratory results: WBC 19.3 K/uL, Hct 25.9%, Plt 546 K/uL, Cr 0.5 mg/dL, Glucose 100 mg/dL, and other labs within normal limits.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

* Septic shock: The patient's fever, tachycardia, and hypotension are consistent with septic shock. The infectious source is not yet clear, but possibilities include urine, decubitus ulcers, pulmonary, abdominal, and right anterior thigh fluid collection.
* Right anterior groin collection: The patient has a probable poly-microbial collection, which may require surgical intervention.
* Decubitus ulcerations: The patient has chronic decubitus ulcers with wound-Vacs in place, which may require wound care nursing consult and continued monitoring for signs of infection.
* Productive cough: The patient has symptoms of an upper respiratory infection, which may be missed due to hypovolemia from sepsis.
* Abdominal pain: The patient has chronic per patient abdominal pain, which may require general surgery consult and continued monitoring.
* Paraplegia: The patient has a history of paraplegia, which may require continued Lovenox, holding for aspiration procedure, and continued home medications.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Organ dysfunction: The patient's septic shock may progress to organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury, respiratory failure, or cardiac dysfunction.
* Infection: The patient's decubitus ulcers, right anterior groin collection, and possible pneumonia may lead to further infection and sepsis.
* Sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy: The patient's septic shock may lead to sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy, which can result in cardiac dysfunction and arrhythmias.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's septic shock and possible pneumonia may lead to respiratory failure, which may require mechanical ventilation.
* Kidney injury: The patient's septic shock may lead to acute kidney injury, which may require dialysis.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical complications, including septic shock, right anterior groin collection, decubitus ulcerations, productive cough, abdominal pain, and paraplegia. The patient requires continued aggressive IVF resuscitation, vasopressor support, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. The patient's condition requires close monitoring, and potential medical complications that can arise include organ dysfunction, infection, sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy, respiratory failure, and kidney injury.

1. Sepsis progression: The patient's sepsis diagnosis is without organ dysfunction, but there is a risk of progression to septic shock or multi-organ dysfunction syndrome.

5. Infection: The patient has a central line, and there is a risk of central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) or other infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI).
6. Thrombosis: The patient is at risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE) due to immobility and hypercoagulability.
7. Organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis diagnosis is without organ dysfunction, but there is a risk of developing organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury (AKI), acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), or hepatic dysfunction.

He was admitted with septic shock from a pelvic abscess and has undergone several interventions, including drainage of the abscess, placement of a drain, and administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

The patient's current condition is critical, with ongoing sepsis and shock. He is being treated with vasopressors and has been weaned off them. His respiratory status is acceptable, with good oxygen saturation, but there is concern about volume overload due to the large amount of fluid administered.

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is ongoing, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
2. Shock: The patient's shock is improving, but there is still a risk of recurrence.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is acceptable, but there is a risk of respiratory failure due to the large amount of fluid administered.
4. Volume overload: The patient has received a large amount of fluid, which may lead to volume overload and further compromise his respiratory status.
5. Infection: The patient's infection is ongoing, and there is a risk of further complications, such as pneumonia or bacteremia.
6. Decubitus ulcers: The patient's decubitus ulcers are chronic and may worsen due to his critical illness.
7. Paraplegia: The patient's paraplegia may worsen due to his critical illness and may require further interventions, such as physical therapy.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hematocrit: 25.9%

The patient's medications include:

* Colace

* Washout of the pelvic abscess

* Fluid management to prevent volume overload
* Wound care for the decubitus ulcers
* Physical therapy to prevent worsening of paraplegia.

Based on the provided medical note, the patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic man with a history of decubitus ulcers, colostomy, and urostomy. He is currently in the ICU with a diagnosis of septic shock and a right hip abscess.

The patient's 24-hour events include the removal of 60cc of fluid from the right hip, which revealed 4+ gram-negative rods and 4+ GPC. He had a SVT/hypotension episode that was converted with adenosine. The patient's blood cultures are positive for gram-positive cocci and long chains, as well as gram-negative rods.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.4째C (97.6째F), heart rate of 65 beats per minute, blood pressure of 103/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 99% on room air.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 19.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 8.1 g/dL, and platelet count of 546 K/uL. His creatinine level is 0.5 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen level is 100 mg/dL.

The patient's medical plan includes the administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam, and azithromycin. He will also receive fluid resuscitation and pressor support as needed.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's diagnosis of septic shock and positive blood cultures indicate that he is at risk for further sepsis.
2. Organ dysfunction: The patient's laboratory results show abnormal values for his white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, which may indicate organ dysfunction.
3. Infection: The patient's right hip abscess and positive blood cultures indicate that he is at risk for further infection.
4. Thrombosis: The patient's diagnosis of septic shock and his use of Lovenox may increase his risk for thrombosis.
5. Malnutrition: The patient's history of paraplegia and his current diagnosis of septic shock may increase his risk for malnutrition.
6. Pressure ulcers: The patient's history of decubitus ulcers and his current diagnosis of septic shock may increase his risk for further pressure ulcers.
7. Inadequate pain management: The patient's use of opioids and benzodiazepines may not be adequate to manage his pain.
8. Inadequate respiratory support: The patient's respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, which may indicate that he is not receiving adequate respiratory support.
9. Inadequate glycemic control: The patient's blood glucose level is 100 mg/dL, which may indicate that he is not receiving adequate glycemic control.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for several medical complications, including sepsis, organ dysfunction, infection, thrombosis, malnutrition, pressure ulcers, inadequate pain management, inadequate respiratory support, and inadequate glycemic control.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic man with a septic hip joint on the right, presenting with fever, tachycardia, and hypotension, consistent with sepsis and septic shock. He has a history of decubitus ulcers, colostomy, and urostomy. The patient has undergone attempted aspiration of the right anterior groin collection, and fluid sent for analysis. The orthopedic service is requesting a washout procedure. The patient is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics, and serial blood cultures are being checked for clearance. He is also receiving fluid resuscitation and pressor support.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis and septic shock: The patient's condition is critical, and he requires close monitoring and aggressive management to prevent further deterioration.
2. Decubitus ulcers: The patient has multiple sacral decubitus ulcers, which are at risk of becoming infected and potentially life-threatening.
3. Right anterior groin collection: The attempted aspiration of the collection may not have been successful, and the patient may require further intervention, such as a washout procedure.
4. Hardware infection: The patient's hardware may become infected, which could lead to further complications and potentially life-threatening consequences.
5. Fluid overload: The patient is receiving aggressive fluid resuscitation, which may lead to fluid overload and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Bloodstream infections: The patient has a history of bloodstream infections, which may be related to the septic hip joint or the decubitus ulcers.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is at risk due to his underlying condition and the potential for respiratory failure.
8. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac status is at risk due to his underlying condition and the potential for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.

   #. Septic shock - Pt w/ fever, leukocytosis and bandemia, all
   supportive of current infection. VS abnormalities c/w septic shock. Pt
   mentating appropriately and currently w/o signs of end-organ damage.
   Infectious source not yet obvious, possibilities includes urine
   (although may be colonized given suprapubic catheter), decubitus ulcers
   (although do not appear infected on exam), pulmonary (given his
   symptoms, although CXR was clear), abdominal (given his tender abdomen,
   although no findings on CT) and right anterior thigh fluid collection.
   Most likely source is right hip/groin abscess given findings from IR
   tap, concern for joint involvement and hardware involvement. C.diff
   negative, Urine Cx neg. Blood Cx +GPCs [**12-26**].
   - cont aggressive IVF resuscitation w/ NS
   - cont vasopressor support until adequately fluid resuscitated
   - cont broad spectrum Abx: Vanc / Zosyn / pending Cx data
   - f/u blood culture, fluid aspirate, send surveillance blood cultures
   - appreciate general surgery and orthopedics consults
   - follow serial labs including lactate, chemistries, blood gases
   #. Right anterior groin collection - S/p attempted wash out of purulent
   material in OR, fluid sent for analysis. Fluid showing probable
   poly-microbial collection.
   - appreciate general surgery and orthopedics consults,
   - cont broad spectrum Abx: Vanc / Zosyn pending Cx data
   #. Decubitus ulcerations - Chronic, currently w/ wound-Vacs in place on
   two separate ulcers.
   - wound care nursing consult
   - contine to monitor for signs of infection
   - would likely be adequately covered with broad-spectrums
   #. Productive cough - Symptoms are likely upper respiratory in origin,
   and clear exam and CXR is consistent. However, given his hypovolemia
   from sepsis, a pneumonia may be missed.
   - consider CXR after adequate IVF resuscitation
   - cont home Albuterol nebs PRN
   - pneumonia would be adequately covered with broad-spectrums
   #. Abdominal pain - Chronic per patient, and symptoms are migratory in
   nature. CT with chronic findings, no acute changes.
   - appreciate general surgery recs
   - cont to monitor
   #. Paraplegia
   - cont Lovenox, holding this morning for aspiration procedure
   - cont home OxyContin, PRN Percocet / Tylenol, Ativan
   - cont home vitamins: Vit B12, iron, folate, MVI
   - cont home bowel regimen: Colace, PRN Senna / Bisacodyl / MoM
   - Nutrition consult
   #. GERD - cont home PPI, PRN antacid
   #. HL - cont home TriCor
   #. Communication - with patient, girlfriend [**Name (NI) 7158**] [**Name (NI) 7159**]
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7160**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic man with decubitus ulcers, colostomy/urostomy, and a history of chronic pain. He was admitted with fever, tachycardia, and hypotension, consistent with sepsis. He has a right anterior groin collection, which was drained and sent for analysis. He is currently receiving aggressive IV fluid resuscitation, vasopressor support, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. He has a history of chronic per patient abdominal pain, which is being monitored. He is also experiencing a productive cough, which is likely upper respiratory in origin, and has a history of GERD.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis-induced organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis could progress to organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury, liver failure, or respiratory failure, if not properly managed.
2. Right anterior groin collection infection: The patient's right anterior groin collection could become infected, leading to further complications, such as abscess formation or sepsis.
3. Decubitus ulcer infection: The patient's decubitus ulcers could become infected, leading to further complications, such as sepsis or osteomyelitis.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's productive cough could be indicative of pneumonia, which would require further evaluation and treatment.
5. Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain could be a sign of a more serious underlying condition, such as pancreatitis or cholecystitis, which would require further evaluation and treatment.
6. Paraplegia: The patient's paraplegia could lead to further complications, such as pressure ulcers, respiratory complications, or autonomic dysreflexia.
7. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition could worsen his overall health and increase his risk of complications.
8. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): The patient's GERD could worsen his symptoms and increase his risk of complications, such as aspiration pneumonia.
9. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's hyperlipidemia could increase his risk of cardiovascular disease and other complications.
10. Communication barriers: The patient's communication barriers could lead to misunderstandings and delays in treatment, which could worsen his condition.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic man admitted to the ICU with sepsis, septic shock, and multiple decubitus ulcers. He has a history of chronic pain, anemia, and gastrointestinal issues. The patient's current condition is characterized by fever, tachycardia, and hypotension, with laboratory results showing leukocytosis, bandemia, and growth of Gram-positive cocci in blood cultures. The patient's wounds are being managed with wound-vacs and drainage, and he is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's septic shock and hypotension may lead to organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, liver dysfunction, or respiratory failure.
2. Decubitus ulcer progression: The patient's chronic decubitus ulcers may worsen due to inadequate wound care, leading to increased risk of infection, tissue necrosis, and potential amputation.
3. Infection spread: The patient's sepsis may spread to other parts of his body, including his lungs, urinary tract, or bloodstream, leading to secondary infections.
4. Anemia and bleeding: The patient's anemia may worsen due to ongoing bleeding, which could lead to hypovolemic shock.
5. Gastrointestinal issues: The patient's gastrointestinal symptoms, including abdominal pain and nausea, may worsen due to sepsis or other underlying conditions.
6. Pneumonia: The patient's hypovolemia and sepsis may increase his risk of developing pneumonia, which could worsen his respiratory status.
7. Venous thromboembolism (VTE): The patient's immobility and sepsis may increase his risk of developing VTE, which could lead to pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.
8. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's chronic pain, anemia, and gastrointestinal issues may lead to nutritional deficiencies, which could worsen his overall condition.
9. Medication-related side effects: The patient's medications, including antibiotics and pain management medications, may cause side effects that worsen his condition.
10. ICU-acquired complications: The patient's prolonged stay in the ICU may increase his risk of developing ICU-acquired complications, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia, catheter-related bloodstream infections, or pressure ulcers.

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a history of right hip infection and drainage of 300cc of frank pus. They have been receiving antibiotics, including azithromycin, vancomycin, and piperacillin/tazobactam. The patient remains pressor-dependent and has a complex medical history with multiple allergies. Their vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.8째C, heart rate of 77 bpm, and blood pressure of 92/47 mmHg. They have a moderate fluid deficit and are receiving IV fluids.

The patient has a diagnosis of sepsis without organ dysfunction and decubitus ulcers present at admission. They are also experiencing acute and chronic pain, alteration in nutrition, and require pain control.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis progression: The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Decubitus ulcers: The patient's decubitus ulcers may worsen, leading to further tissue damage and potential complications such as infection or gangrene.
3. Infection: The patient's Gram-positive cocci infection may spread to other areas of the body, leading to further complications.
4. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid deficit may worsen, leading to fluid overload and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Nutritional compromise: The patient's alteration in nutrition may lead to malnutrition, which can further compromise their overall health.
6. Pain management: The patient's chronic pain may not be adequately managed, leading to discomfort and potentially worsening their overall condition.
7. Thrombosis: The patient's pressor dependence may increase their risk of thrombosis, particularly deep vein thrombosis.
8. VAP: The patient's risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) is increased due to their prolonged ICU stay and pressor dependence.
9. Wound infection: The patient's wound may become infected, leading to further complications and potentially life-threatening outcomes.
10. Organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis may lead to organ dysfunction, particularly in the kidneys, liver, or lungs, which can further compromise their overall health.

The patient underwent surgery for right hip infection and drainage of 300cc of frank pus. They remain pressor-dependent and are receiving various medications, including antibiotics, antacids, and pain management medications.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.9째C, heart rate of 77bpm, and blood pressure of 92/47mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with an SpO2 of 99% and no oxygen delivery device in use.

The patient's laboratory results show signs of infection, including a white blood cell count of 19.3K/uL, hemoglobin of 7.7g/dL, and lactate level of 1.3mmol/L. The patient's coagulation profile is abnormal, with a prolonged PT and PTT.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their unstable condition, and therefore, many areas of the examination were not assessed. The patient's skin was not assessed, and their peripheral vascular examination was incomplete.

The patient's medical history is significant for unknown allergies to ivp dye, iodine-containing substances, Motrin, Aspirin, and an unknown antibiotic. The patient's family history is not mentioned.

The patient's laboratory results suggest a possible source of infection in the right hip, with a Gram-positive cocci infection identified in the aspirated thigh fluid and fluid culture. The patient's blood cultures are pending.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis progression: The patient's sepsis may worsen, leading to organ dysfunction and potential mortality.
2. Decubitus ulcer progression: The patient's decubitus ulcer may worsen, leading to further tissue damage and potential complications.
3. Infection spread: The patient's infection may spread to other areas of the body, leading to further complications.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's abnormal coagulation profile may lead to bleeding complications.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's alteration in nutrition may lead to malnutrition and potential complications.
6. Pain management: The patient's chronic pain may not be adequately managed, leading to further complications.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate, leading to respiratory failure.
8. Cardiac complications: The patient's pressor dependency may lead to cardiac complications, such as hypertension and cardiac arrhythmias.

Given the patient's unstable condition and multiple potential complications, close monitoring and aggressive management are necessary to prevent or treat these complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic man admitted to the ICU with a septic hip joint on the right, septic shock, and multiple decubitus ulcers. He has a history of colostomy and urostomy and is currently on broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.8째C, heart rate of 77 bpm, and blood pressure of 92/47 mmHg. He has a central line, arterial line, and femoral venous catheter in place. His laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, and lactate levels, as well as decreased hemoglobin and platelet count.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's septic shock and elevated lactate levels may lead to organ dysfunction, including respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal failure.
2. Decubitus ulcer progression: The patient's multiple decubitus ulcers may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further complications such as infection, necrosis, and potentially life-threatening events.
3. Central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI): The patient's central line may become infected, leading to sepsis and potential organ dysfunction.
4. Venous thromboembolism (VTE): The patient's paraplegia and immobility may increase his risk of VTE, which could lead to pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's malnutrition and decreased appetite may lead to deficiencies in essential nutrients, including vitamins and minerals.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's colostomy and urostomy may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly if his anticoagulation therapy is not properly managed.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's sepsis and respiratory symptoms may worsen, leading to respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening events.
8. Cardiac complications: The patient's sepsis and cardiovascular instability may lead to cardiac complications, including arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiogenic shock.

Based on this information, it is essential to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status closely, and to adjust his treatment plan as needed to prevent or manage potential complications.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.8째C, heart rate of 77 bpm, and blood pressure of 92/47 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support is minimal, with an oxygen saturation of 99% and no respiratory distress.

The patient has several potential medical complications that can arise, including:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is likely to worsen if not properly managed, leading to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Decubitus ulcers: The patient's chronic decubitus ulcers are at risk of worsening if not properly managed, leading to further complications such as infection and tissue damage.

6. Infection: The patient's multiple medical conditions and immobility make him at risk of developing infection, which can be life-threatening if not properly managed.
7. Hardware infection: The patient's hardware (e.g., colostomy/urostomy) may become infected, leading to further complications and potentially life-threatening outcomes.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continued antibiotics to manage sepsis
2. Wound care and management of decubitus ulcers
3. Pain control and management
4. Nutrition support and management

6. Monitoring for signs of infection and sepsis
7. Communication with the patient and his caregivers to ensure proper management and treatment.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-year-old individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a diagnosis of sepsis without organ dysfunction, decubitus ulcer, and acute pain. The patient underwent an emergency right hip irrigation and debridement with vacuum-assisted closure (VAC). The patient has a history of allergies to ivp dye, iodine-containing substances, and unknown medications including Motrin, Aspirin, and antibiotics.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.8째C, heart rate of 77 beats per minute, blood pressure of 92/47 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 99% without supplemental oxygen.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 19.3 K/uL, anemia with a hemoglobin level of 7.7 g/dL, and thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 546 K/uL. The patient's liver function tests are within normal limits, and the patient's creatinine level is 0.5 mg/dL.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to the patient's altered mental status and inability to assess peripheral pulses, skin, and neurologic status.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis progression: The patient's sepsis diagnosis is without organ dysfunction, but the patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, anemia, and thrombocytopenia, which may indicate a progression of sepsis.
2. Decubitus ulcer progression: The patient's decubitus ulcer is present at admission, and the patient's immobility in the ICU may lead to further progression of the ulcer.
3. Pain management: The patient's acute pain from the surgical procedure and chronic pain from the decubitus ulcer need to be managed to prevent further complications.
4. Nutrition: The patient's alteration in nutrition may lead to malnutrition, which can worsen the patient's overall condition.
5. Infection: The patient's presence in the ICU increases the risk of infection, particularly ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs).
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may increase the risk of bleeding complications, particularly in the setting of invasive procedures.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, particularly in the setting of hypotension.
8. Liver dysfunction: The patient's liver function tests are within normal limits, but the patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, which may indicate liver dysfunction.

Based on the patient's diagnosis and laboratory results, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and manage the patient's sepsis, decubitus ulcer, pain, and nutrition. Additionally, the patient's thrombocytopenia and anemia need to be addressed to prevent bleeding and cardiovascular complications.

   Presented [**4-19**] in septic shock initially with f/c/sob and productive
   cough of white sputum, light headiness, increased thirst and nausea.
   He was febrile and tachy at NH with BP 98/60, pulse up to 180 and
   received adenosine by EMS during transport to [**Hospital1 19**].  In ED, tachy and
   hypotensive.  T 101, P 150, BP 70/40  RR 17 100% NRB and room air.
   Left IJ CVL inserted, started on neosynephrine, and given 4 L IV
   fluids.  Abdomen tender though patient reports this is at baseline.
   Labs WBC 23 with 17% bands, Cr 1.3 lactate 4.7.  UA from suprapubic
   cath shows 21wbc and bacteria.  Cultures sent, pt given vanc 22:00
   /zosyn 23:00/azithro.  CT abd/pelvis shows a fluid collection with rim
   enhancement in the right pelvis. Drain was placed by IR with drainage
   of pus [**4-20**]. Gram stain shows 3+ polys with GNRs and GPCs in pairs and
   chains.
   Overnight/day events notable for: strep from abscess (and per micro the
   strep isolated in the BC) is now speciated as S anginosis.
   Sensitivities usually not run on this due to usually exquisite
   sensitivity to PCN.
   Exam as above. Awake, alert, oriented. Chest clear ant/lat, S1S2 reg,
   no murmurs, abd 2+ pitting LE edema.
   Labs, meds reviewed.
   Episode of SVT [**4-20**] with no recurrence. Labs significant for improving
   leukocytosis, creat. Still on pressors. Went to the OR yesterday for
   washout of pelvic abscess with 300 cc of additional pus drained.
   Remains on Vanc/Zosyn. Overall improving sepsis with continued shock,
   likely still septic. Respiratory status acceptable with good sats but
   concern for volume overload (LOS ~ 15 L positive including ED fluids).
   Management of strep mileri was reviewed. It is unusual for small colony
   S mileri to cause endocarditis (but micro not able to tell us small vs
   large). It is indicated to obtain an echo to r/o endocarditis -
   ordered. We also decided to give a dose of Gent for synergy given
   persistent shock. Cortisol 11
 will check ACTH stim test.
   Rest of the plan as outlined above in Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 7173**]
s note. Patient is
   critically ill. Total time 35 minutes. Full code.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic man with a history of decubitus ulcers, urostomy, and ostomy, who presents with septic shock, fever, tachycardia, and hypotension. He has a concerning right hip abscess as the source of sepsis shock. He has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, Vanc and Zosyn, and remains on low-dose pressors.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis shock: The patient's septic shock is likely to continue, and he may require further management, including adjustment of antibiotics and pressors.
2. Right hip abscess: The abscess may continue to drain, and the patient may require further drainage or surgical intervention.
3. Decubitus ulcerations: The patient's chronic decubitus ulcers may continue to progress, and he may require ongoing wound care and management.
4. Paraplegia: The patient's paraplegia may lead to complications such as pressure sores, respiratory problems, and urinary retention.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's chronic illness and immobility may lead to malnutrition, and he may require ongoing nutritional support.
6. Respiratory problems: The patient's respiratory status may continue to deteriorate, and he may require further management, including oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's septic shock may lead to cardiovascular complications, including cardiac arrhythmias and heart failure.
8. Infection: The patient may develop secondary infections, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, or bloodstream infections.
9. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's gastrointestinal status may continue to deteriorate, and he may require further management, including bowel regimens and nutritional support.
10. Hematological complications: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia may continue to worsen, and he may require further management, including blood transfusions and platelet support.

Recommendations:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics, Vanc and Zosyn, and monitor for signs of improvement or worsening sepsis.
2. Consider surgical intervention to drain the right hip abscess and manage any associated complications.
3. Continue wound care and management for the decubitus ulcers, and consider surgical intervention if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's paraplegia and adjust management as necessary to prevent complications.
5. Provide ongoing nutritional support, including enteral nutrition and vitamin supplements.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust management as necessary to prevent complications.
7. Consider cardiovascular support, including cardiac monitoring and vasopressor therapy, to manage potential cardiovascular complications.
8. Monitor for signs of secondary infections and adjust management as necessary.
9. Consider gastrointestinal support, including bowel regimens and nutritional support, to manage potential gastrointestinal complications.
10. Monitor the patient's hematological status and adjust management as necessary to prevent complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

The patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic male with a history of decubitus ulcers, colostomy, and urostomy, who presents with fever, tachycardia, and hypotension, consistent with sepsis. He has a concerning right hip abscess as the source of sepsis and shock.

The patient has received broad-spectrum antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam, and is still requiring low-dose pressors. His blood cultures and fluid aspirate are pending, and serial blood cultures have been negative.

The patient has multiple medical conditions, including paraplegia, decubitus ulcers, and chronic bowel obstruction, which require ongoing management. He is receiving anticoagulation therapy with lovenox and has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Sepsis and septic shock: The patient's current septic shock status requires close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration.
2. Decubitus ulcer infections: The patient's chronic decubitus ulcers are at risk of infection, which can lead to further complications and prolonged hospitalization.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and ongoing anticoagulation therapy increase the risk of further bleeding complications.
4. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's high-dose lovenox therapy may increase the risk of DVT, which can lead to pulmonary embolism and other complications.
5. Wound complications: The patient's chronic wounds may become infected, leading to further complications and prolonged hospitalization.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory disease and potential respiratory complications from sepsis and shock require close monitoring and management.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's septic shock and potential cardiovascular instability require close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

In conclusion, the patient requires ongoing close monitoring and management of his multiple medical conditions, including sepsis, decubitus ulcers, and chronic bowel obstruction, to prevent further complications and promote recovery.

The patient has a growing Streptococcus anginosus (Strep milleri group) infection in their thigh fluid and blood, which is being treated with gentamicin, vancomycin, and piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn). The patient also has a sacral decubitus ulcer that communicates with the area of the thigh abscess and has been diagnosed with osteomyelitis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4째C, heart rate of 59 beats per minute, blood pressure of 109/63 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98%. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure (CVP) of 4 mmHg, and their fluid balance is positive with a total fluid intake of 2,093 mL and a total fluid output of 2,670 mL.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and neutrophil count, with a WBC of 19.3 and a neutrophil count of 11.8 K/uL. The patient's hemoglobin (Hb) level is 7.9 g/dL, and their platelet count is 552 K/uL. The patient's creatinine (Cr) level is 0.5 mg/dL, and their blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 22 mEq/L.

The patient's imaging studies show mild thickening of the mitral leaflets with mild mitral regurgitation on echocardiogram (ECHO). The patient's microbiology results show Streptococcus anginosus in their blood and abscess cultures.

The patient's assessment and plan include sepsis without organ dysfunction, decubitus ulcer, pain control, alteration in nutrition, and ICU care. The patient is receiving antibiotics, pain management, and nutritional support. The patient's disposition is to remain in the ICU.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's conditions include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's growing Streptococcus anginosus infection can lead to sepsis, which can cause organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Osteomyelitis: The patient's osteomyelitis can lead to further bone destruction, infection, and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Decubitus ulcer: The patient's decubitus ulcer can lead to further tissue damage, infection, and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Endocarditis: The patient's mild mitral regurgitation and lack of discrete vegetation on echocardiogram suggest a possible diagnosis of endocarditis, which can lead to further cardiac complications.
5. Renal dysfunction: The patient's elevated BUN level and Cr level suggest potential renal dysfunction, which can worsen with further infection and inflammation.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's alteration in nutrition can lead to malnutrition, which can worsen with further infection and inflammation.
7. Pain management: The patient's acute and chronic pain requires proper management to prevent further complications and ensure optimal patient care.

   58-yo paraplegic man with decubitus ulcers with Vac drains, colostomy /
   urostomy, who presents with fever, tachycardia, and hypotension, c/w
   sepsis.
   #. Septic shock
 Ongoing septic shock, unable to wean from pressors
   although dose is [**Month (only) **], Svo2 87 c/w poor perfusion. No further fevers and
   WBC is [**Month (only) **] which does suggest some improvement. Patient has been
   mentating well. Did appear to have reduced GFR which has now improved.
   Source is right hip wound growing strep arginosus and secondary
   bacteremia in [**1-26**] on admission. Bacteremia has cleared. TTE showed no
   vegetation but poor study. Pt is s/p washout in OR but there are plans
   for repeat washout tomorrow. It is concerning that the patient has
   still not been able to come of pressors. Etiologies include inadequate
   abx, inadequate source control with ongoing bacteremia, adrenal
   insuficiency. Inadequate abx is still possible as sensitivities are
   still being done; however,  Vanc levsl are adequate and strep milleri
   group should be sensitive to PCN and Vanc. The patient was given one
   dose of gent.  Inadequate source control seems unlikely as pt has had
   wash out, has wound vacs in place and as there is no vegetation on echo
   to suggest ongoing endovascular sourse
 may consider TEE but
   endocarditis is rare in strep milleri particularly with small colony
   strep ( which is what the patient
s presentation is most c/w).
   Cortisol levels have been checked as well as [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim and is nl r/o
   adrenal insufficiency. TSH is also normal. Of note, patient is making a
   lot of  urine
 200cc/hr- which raises the question if post-ATN
   diuresis is making him intravascularly dry.
   - cont vasopressor support until adequately fluid resuscitated
   - check Vanc level troughs
   - f/u blood culture, fluid aspirate, send surveillance blood cultures
   - appreciate general surgery and orthopedics consults
   - follow serial labs including lactate, chemistries, blood gases
   #. Right anterior groin collection
 Decubitous ulcer communicateds
   with groin collection per plastics. S/p wash out of purulent material
   in OR, fluid sent for analysis. Fluid showing probable poly-microbial
   collection.
   - appreciate general surgery and orthopedics consults,
   - will need repeat OR later this week
   # Anemia:
   - repeat HCT in PM, transfuse for Hg <7
   #. Decubitus ulcerations - Chronic, currently w/ wound-Vacs in place on
   two separate ulcers.
   - appreciate plastics involvment
   - wound care nursing consult
   - contine to monitor for signs of infection
   - would likely be adequately covered with broad-spectrums
   #. Productive cough - Symptoms are likely upper respiratory in origin,
   and clear exam and CXR is consistent. However, given his hypovolemia
   from sepsis, a pneumonia may be missed.
   - consider CXR after adequate IVF resuscitation
   - cont home Albuterol nebs PRN
   - pneumonia would be adequately covered with broad-spectrums
   #. Abdominal pain - Chronic per patient, and symptoms are migratory in
   nature. CT with chronic findings, no acute changes.
   - appreciate general surgery recs

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic man admitted to the ICU with sepsis, decubitus ulcers, and a history of chronic pain. He has been treated with antibiotics and has shown some improvement, but remains on vasopressors and has not been able to wean off them. The patient has a right hip wound that is infected with Streptococcus anginosus, and has had a washout procedure to debride the wound. He also has a colostomy and urostomy.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis has not fully resolved, and he remains at risk for further complications, including organ dysfunction and death.
2. Decubitus ulcers: The patient's decubitus ulcers are at risk for further deterioration and potential infection.
3. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's cortisol levels are equivocal, and he has been treated with hydrocortisone. Further evaluation is needed to determine if he has adrenal insufficiency.
4. Endocarditis: Although the patient's echo was suboptimal, it did not show any vegetation, which reduces the risk of endocarditis. However, the patient's symptoms and lab results suggest that he may have a source of bacteremia, and further evaluation is needed to rule out endocarditis.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's symptoms and CXR are consistent with pneumonia, and further evaluation is needed to confirm this diagnosis.
6. Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain is likely related to his decubitus ulcers, but further evaluation is needed to determine if there is an underlying cause.
7. Paraplegia: The patient's paraplegia is a chronic condition, but further evaluation is needed to determine if there are any underlying causes or complications.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely related to his chronic pain and decreased mobility, but further evaluation is needed to determine if there is an underlying cause.
9. Productive cough: The patient's productive cough is likely related to his upper respiratory infection, but further evaluation is needed to determine if there is an underlying cause.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's sepsis and adjust his antibiotic therapy as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's decubitus ulcers and provide wound care as needed.
3. Continue to evaluate the patient's adrenal function and provide hydrocortisone as needed.
4. Consider further evaluation of the patient's endocarditis, including a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE).
5. Consider further evaluation of the patient's pneumonia, including a chest CT scan.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's abdominal pain and adjust his pain management as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's paraplegia and adjust his pain management as needed.
8. Consider further evaluation of the patient's anemia, including a complete blood count (CBC) and reticulocyte count.
9. Consider further evaluation of the patient's productive cough, including a chest CT scan.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic man admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of sepsis without organ dysfunction, decubitus ulcers, and pain control issues. The patient has a history of chronic pain, colostomy/urostomy, and Vac drains.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tmax 36.4째C, Tcurrent 35.8째C, HR 59 bpm, BP 109/63 mmHg, RR 12 inspirations per minute, SpO2 98%.
* Laboratory results: WBC 19.3 K/uL, Hct 24.3%, Plt 552 K/uL, Cr 0.5 mg/dL, Glucose 100 mg/dL.
* Imaging: ECHO shows mild thickening of the mitral leaflets with mild mitral regurgitation, no discrete vegetation identified.
* Microbiology: Blood culture shows Streptococcus anginosus, abscess culture also shows Streptococcus anginosus, and OR culture shows GPC.
* Assessment and plan: The patient is still septic, unable to wean from pressors, and has not been able to come off them. The source of the infection is the right hip wound growing Streptococcus anginosus and secondary bacteremia. The patient has had a washout in the OR, and plans are for repeat washout tomorrow.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Inadequate antibiotic coverage, leading to persistent bacteremia and sepsis.
* Inadequate source control, leading to ongoing infection and sepsis.
* Adrenal insufficiency, which is suggested by the patient's cortisol levels.
* Post-ATN diuresis, which may be causing intravascular dryness and hypotension.
* Pneumonia, which may be missed due to the patient's hypovolemia from sepsis.
* Decubitus ulcer infections, which may be complicated by the patient's chronic decubitus ulcers and Vac drains.
* Osteomyelitis, which is suspected based on the patient's bone exam.
* Endocarditis, although rare in Streptococcus anginosus, particularly with small colony Streptococcus.

The patient requires close monitoring and management of his sepsis, antibiotic therapy, and source control. He also requires further evaluation and management of his adrenal function, potential post-ATN diuresis, and decubitus ulcer infections.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis progression to septic shock: The patient's sepsis without organ dysfunction may progress to septic shock if not properly managed.
2. Decubitus ulcer progression: The patient's decubitus ulcer may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further complications such as infection and tissue damage.
3. Pain management issues: The patient's acute and chronic pain may not be adequately managed, leading to discomfort, distress, and potential complications such as respiratory depression.

5. Glycemic control issues: The patient's glycemic control may not be adequately managed, leading to hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia, which can have serious consequences.
6. Line-related complications: The patient's multiple lines may be at risk for complications such as infection, bleeding, or occlusion.
7. DVT and VTE: The patient is at risk for DVT and VTE due to immobility and other factors, which can lead to serious complications such as pulmonary embolism.
8. Stress ulcer and gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's stress ulcer may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding, which can be life-threatening.
9. Respiratory failure: The patient's altered nutrition and other factors may lead to respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.
10. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and other factors may lead to infection, which can be life-threatening.

The patient, a 58-year-old paraplegic man, is being treated for septic hip joint on the right. He has a history of decubitus ulcers, colostomy/urostomy, and is currently receiving treatment for sepsis. He is experiencing persistent hypotension and requires low-dose pressors.

The patient's vital signs are:

The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, pain management medications, and anticoagulants.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 19.3 K/uL (15.6 K/uL - 15.5 K/uL - 11.8 K/uL)

The patient has been experiencing decubitus ulcers and has undergone wound care and surgery. He is also at risk for hardware infection and is being monitored for this.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Further deterioration of the patient's septic shock

* Nutritional deficiencies and electrolyte imbalances due to the patient's chronic illness and treatment

Based on the patient's progress, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to identify any potential complications early and adjust treatment accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic male admitted to the ICU with septic hip joint on the right, fever, tachycardia, and hypotension, consistent with sepsis. He has decubitus ulcers, a colostomy/urostomy, and is on broad-spectrum antibiotics (Vanc/Zosyn) for sepsis. The patient's vital signs are stable, but he requires low-dose pressors to maintain blood pressure. He has a history of chronic pain, and his pain is managed with oxycodone and other medications. The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, thrombocytopenia, and elevated lactate levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis-related organ dysfunction: The patient's sepsis may progress to septic shock, leading to organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and hepatic dysfunction.
2. Decubitus ulcer infection: The patient's decubitus ulcers may become infected, leading to cellulitis, abscesses, or sepsis.
3. Wound complications: The patient's wounds may not heal properly, leading to prolonged hospitalization, increased risk of infection, and potential need for surgical intervention.
4. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's altered nutrition and malabsorption may lead to deficiencies in vitamins, minerals, and proteins, exacerbating his underlying conditions.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's colostomy/urostomy may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding, obstruction, or perforation.
6. Blood clotting disorders: The patient's prolonged hospitalization and immobilization may increase his risk of developing blood clotting disorders, including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
7. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's prolonged hospitalization and treatment may lead to electrolyte imbalances, including hyperkalemia, hypokalemia, and hypocalcemia.
8. Infection-related complications: The patient's sepsis may lead to infection-related complications, including meningitis, endocarditis, and osteomyelitis.
9. Respiratory complications: The patient's sepsis may lead to respiratory complications, including acute respiratory distress syndrome, pneumonia, and respiratory failure.
10. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's sepsis may lead to cardiovascular complications, including cardiac arrest, arrhythmias, and cardiogenic shock.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic male with a history of decubitus ulcers, colostomy/urostomy, and a right hip abscess. He is currently in the ICU due to septic shock, which is likely caused by the hip abscess.

The patient's condition is complex, and several potential medical complications can arise. Some of these complications include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is likely to persist, and there is a risk of developing further septic episodes.
2. Hypovolemic shock: The patient's hypotension may be due to hypovolemic shock, which can occur if he is not adequately hydrated.
3. Osteomyelitis: The patient's hip abscess may lead to osteomyelitis, which can cause further bone damage and potentially lead to amputation.
4. Decubitus ulcerations: The patient's decubitus ulcers are at risk of worsening, which can lead to further tissue damage and potentially life-threatening infections.
5. Paraplegia: The patient's paraplegia may worsen due to further damage to his spinal cord or surrounding tissues.
6. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status is currently acceptable, but there is a risk of developing respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or respiratory failure, due to his underlying conditions.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutritional status is compromised, and there is a risk of developing further deficiencies, such as malnutrition or electrolyte imbalances.
8. Infection: The patient's septic shock may lead to further infections, such as bacteremia or sepsis, which can be life-threatening.

The patient's treatment plan includes antibiotics, wound care, and surgical interventions. The patient will require close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic man with a septic hip joint on the right, decubitus ulcers, colostomy/urostomy, and a history of polymicrobial hip abscess and osteomyelitis. The patient is currently being treated with antibiotics, including Gentamicin, Vancomycin, and Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn), and is receiving pressor support for hypotension.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic hip joint and polymicrobial hip abscess and osteomyelitis put him at risk for further sepsis, which can lead to organ failure and death.
2. Osteomyelitis: The patient's polymicrobial hip abscess and osteomyelitis can lead to further bone destruction and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Decubitus ulcers: The patient's chronic decubitus ulcers can lead to further skin breakdown, infection, and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Hypotension: The patient's persistent hypotension requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.
5. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and decreased blood pressure put him at risk for renal failure.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory disease and decreased blood pressure put him at risk for respiratory failure.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's decreased blood pressure and chronic cardiovascular disease put him at risk for cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrest.

To manage these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored and treated with antibiotics, pressors, and other medications as necessary. The patient should also be closely monitored for signs of sepsis, osteomyelitis, and decubitus ulcers, and should receive regular wound care and dressing changes. The patient's nutritional status should also be closely monitored, and he should receive regular diet and nutrition counseling.

   58-yo paraplegic man with decubitus ulcers with Vac drains, colostomy /
   urostomy, who presents with fever, tachycardia, and hypotension, c/w
   sepsis.
   #. Septic shock
 Ongoing septic shock, unable to wean from pressors
   although dose is [**Month (only) **], Svo2 87 c/w poor perfusion. No further fevers and
   WBC is [**Month (only) **] which does suggest some improvement. Patient has been
   mentating well. Did appear to have reduced GFR which has now improved.
   Source is right hip wound growing strep arginosus and secondary
   bacteremia in [**1-26**] on admission. Bacteremia has cleared. TTE showed no
   vegetation but poor study. Pt is s/p washout in OR but there are plans
   for repeat washout tomorrow. It is concerning that the patient has
   still not been able to come of pressors. Etiologies include inadequate
   abx, inadequate source control with ongoing bacteremia, adrenal
   insuficiency. Inadequate abx is still possible as sensitivities are
   still being done; however, Vanc levels are adequate and strep milleri
   group should be sensitive to PCN and Vanc. The patient was given one
   dose of gent.  Inadequate source control seems unlikely as pt has had
   wash out, has wound vacs in place and as there is no vegetation on echo
   to suggest ongoing endovascular sourse
 may consider TEE but
   endocarditis is rare in strep milleri particularly with small colony
   strep ( which is what the patient
s presentation is most c/w).
   Cortisol levels have been checked as well as [**Last Name (un) 402**] stim and is nl r/o
   adrenal insufficiency. TSH is also normal. Of note, patient is making a
   lot of urine
 200cc/hr- which raises the question if post-ATN diuresis
   is making him intravascularly dry.
   - cont vasopressor support for now
   - Per ID, will cont Vanc/Zosyn for now, but may transition to
   CTX/Flagyl
   - f/u cx data
   - appreciate general surgery and orthopedics consults
   - follow serial labs including lactate, chemistries, blood gases
   #. Right anterior groin collection
 Decubitous ulcer communicateds
   with groin collection per plastics. S/p wash out of purulent material
   in OR, fluid sent for analysis. Fluid showing probable poly-microbial
   collection.
   - appreciate general surgery and orthopedics consults,
   - Ortho to take back to OR today for another washout
   - NPO after MN and hold AM dose of lovenox
   # Anemia:
   - repeat HCT in PM, transfuse for Hg <7
   #. Decubitus ulcerations - Chronic, currently w/ wound-Vacs in place on
   two separate ulcers.
   - appreciate plastics involvment
   - wound care nursing consult
   - contine to monitor for signs of infection
   - would likely be adequately covered with broad-spectrums
   #. Productive cough - Symptoms are likely upper respiratory in origin,
   and clear exam and CXR is consistent. However, given his hypovolemia
   from sepsis, a pneumonia may be missed.
   - consider CXR after adequate IVF resuscitation
   - cont home Albuterol nebs PRN
   #. Abdominal pain - Chronic per patient, and symptoms are migratory in
   nature. CT with chronic findings, no acute changes.
   - simethicone PRN
   - appreciate general surgery recs
   - cont to monitor
   #. Paraplegia
   - cont Lovenox [**Hospital1 **] will  need to hold for OR tomorrow
   - cont home OxyContin, PRN Percocet / Tylenol, Ativan
   - cont home vitamins: Vit B12, iron, folate, MVI
   - cont home bowel regimen: Colace, PRN Senna / Bisacodyl / MoM
   - Nutrition consult
   #. GERD - cont home PPI, PRN antacid
   #. HL - cont home TriCor
   #. Communication - with patient, girlfriend [**Name (NI) 7158**] [**Name (NI) 7159**]
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7160**]

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic man with a decubitus ulcer, colostomy, and urostomy, who presented with fever, tachycardia, and hypotension, consistent with sepsis. He has been diagnosed with septic shock, unable to wean from pressors, and has a right hip wound growing Streptococcus anginosus and secondary bacteremia. The patient has undergone a washout in the operating room, but plans for repeat washout tomorrow are in place. The patient's source control seems adequate, but inadequate antibiotic therapy and adrenal insufficiency are potential etiologies for his ongoing septic shock.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Septic shock: The patient is already experiencing septic shock, which can lead to multi-organ failure, including respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal failure.
2. Inadequate antibiotic therapy: The patient's antibiotic regimen may not be adequate to cover the infection, leading to continued bacteremia and septic shock.
3. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's cortisol levels and ACTH stimulation test are normal, but adrenal insufficiency is still a possibility, which can exacerbate septic shock.
4. Post-ATN diuresis: The patient's high urine output (200cc/hr) may indicate post-ATN diuresis, which can lead to intravascular dehydration.
5. Decubitus ulcer complications: The patient's decubitus ulcers are chronic and may become infected, leading to further complications.
6. Pneumonia: Given the patient's hypovolemia from sepsis, a pneumonia may be missed, which can lead to respiratory failure.
7. Abdominal pain: The patient's abdominal pain is chronic and migratory, and may be related to his decubitus ulcers or other underlying conditions.
8. Paraplegia: The patient's paraplegia may be complicated by pressure ulcers, skin breakdown, and other secondary complications.

Overall, the patient's septic shock requires close monitoring and management, and potential complications should be anticipated and addressed promptly to prevent further deterioration.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic man with a history of decubitus ulcers, colostomy, and urostomy, who was admitted with sepsis, septic shock, and a right hip wound infection. The patient's condition is currently stable, but he is still receiving vasopressor support and has not been able to wean off pressors.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 19.3 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit (Hct): 25.9%
* Platelet count (Plt): 546 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine (Cr): 0.5 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 7.4 mg/dL
* Glucose: 100 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.3 mmol/L
* Calcium: 7.2 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.3 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Right hip wound infection with streptococcus anginosus (milleri) group
* No vegetation on echocardiogram (TTE) to suggest ongoing endovascular source
* Abnormal renal function tests (RFTs) with elevated creatinine and BUN

The patient's medical history is significant for decubitus ulcers, chronic pain, and paraplegia. He is currently receiving antibiotics, including vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam, and has had a washout procedure in the operating room.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis and septic shock
* Endocarditis
* Adrenal insufficiency
* Post-ATN diuresis
* Hypovolemia
* Pneumonia
* Decubitus ulcer infection
* Chronic pain and paraplegia
* Malnutrition
* Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
* Hyperlipidemia (HL)
* Communication difficulties

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuation of antibiotics and vasopressor support
* Repeat wound care and debridement
* Monitoring of laboratory results and imaging studies
* Nutrition consultation and support
* Pain management
* Communication with the patient and his family members

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic man with decubitus ulcers, colostomy, and urostomy, who presents with septic shock, fever, tachycardia, and hypotension. He has a right hip abscess growing Streptococcus and Gram-negative rods, and is receiving antibiotics. He has a history of chronic decubitus ulcerations and is at risk for further complications. He is also taking various medications, including anticoagulants, antacids, and vitamins.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate attention. If not treated promptly, it can lead to organ failure and death.
2. Decubitus ulcerations: The patient's chronic decubitus ulcerations are at risk of further complications, including infection, necrosis, and sepsis.
3. Abscess formation: The patient's right hip abscess is a potential source of further complications, including sepsis, abscess rupture, and osteomyelitis.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's paraplegia and recent surgery may increase his risk of neurological complications, including spinal cord compression, meningitis, and sepsis.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's colostomy and urostomy may increase his risk of gastrointestinal complications, including obstruction, perforation, and sepsis.
6. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's septic shock and hypotension may increase his risk of cardiovascular complications, including cardiac arrest, myocardial infarction, and congestive heart failure.
7. Respiratory complications: The patient's septic shock and hypotension may increase his risk of respiratory complications, including respiratory failure, pneumonia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
8. Renal complications: The patient's septic shock and hypotension may increase his risk of renal complications, including acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and end-stage renal disease.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics as prescribed and monitor for signs of infection.
2. Monitor the patient's vital signs, including temperature, heart rate, and blood pressure, and adjust his treatment plan as necessary.
3. Continue to manage the patient's decubitus ulcerations with wound care and consider surgical debridement if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's neurological status and consider imaging studies to rule out abscess or other complications.
5. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and consider adjusting his bowel regimen as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and consider adjusting his treatment plan as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider adjusting his treatment plan as necessary.
8. Monitor the patient's renal status and consider adjusting his treatment plan as necessary.
9. Consider consulting with a specialist, such as a neurologist or a gastroenterologist, to further evaluate the patient's condition and develop a comprehensive treatment plan.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old paraplegic man with decubitus ulcers, colostomy/urostomy, who is currently in the ICU due to septic shock secondary to a right hip abscess. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7째C, heart rate of 68 bpm, and blood pressure of 106/53 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 19.3 K/uL, hemoglobin of 7.4 g/dL, and platelet count of 546 K/uL. The patient's electrolytes are within normal limits, with a sodium level of 139 mEq/L, potassium level of 4.1 mEq/L, and chloride level of 107 mEq/L.

The patient's medical conditions include septic shock, polymicrobial hip abscess and osteomyelitis, decubitus ulcerations, paraplegia, GERD, hyperlipidemia, and alteration in nutrition. The patient is receiving antibiotics for the polymicrobial hip abscess and osteomyelitis, and is being treated with vasopressors to maintain blood pressure.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Further deterioration of the patient's septic shock, leading to organ dysfunction or failure.
2. Development of respiratory failure due to the patient's chronic respiratory disease.
3. Increased risk of bleeding due to the patient's thrombocytopenia.
4. Development of kidney injury or failure due to the patient's sepsis and hypotension.
5. Development of wound infections or further deterioration of the patient's decubitus ulcers.
6. Increased risk of cardiovascular events due to the patient's hyperlipidemia.
7. Development of electrolyte imbalances or acid-base disorders due to the patient's altered nutrition and electrolyte levels.

In order to prevent these complications, the patient should receive close monitoring and management of his septic shock, respiratory status, and electrolyte levels. The patient's antibiotics should be continued and adjusted as necessary, and the patient should be closely monitored for signs of infection or further deterioration of his condition.

   examined the patient on this date.  I agree with the findings as
   described above including history, exam, ROS, Fam Hx and assessment and
   plan.  I would add/emphasize the following:
   History reviewed. 58 yo ex-60 py smoker, paraplegic, decubitus ulcers,
   urostomy, ostomy, LUL T2N0 poorly diff adenoCA, multiple pneumothoraces
   s/p pleurodesis admitted with septic shock likely from pelvic abscess.
   CT abd/pelvis showed a 6 cm in diameter fluid collection with rim
   enhancement in the right pelvis. Drain was placed by IR with drainage
   of pus [**4-20**]. Gram stain shows 3+ polys with GNRs and GPCs in pairs and
   chains, grew S mileri sensitive to PCN.
   Episode of SVT [**4-20**] with no recurrence. Labs significant for improving
   leukocytosis, creat. Still on pressors. Went to the OR [**4-21**] for washout
   of pelvic abscess with 300 cc of additional pus drained, and washed out
   again today
 reportedly no pus.
   Overnight/day events notable for: washout in OR today, swab from wound
   and bone sent for culture.
   TTE [**4-23**] showed limited views but normal biventricular function, no
   vegetations seen. ACTH stim test showed cortisol increase from 11 to
   20.
   Exam unchanged. Awake, alert, oriented. Chest clear ant/lat, S1S2 reg,
   no audible murmurs, abd 2+ pitting LE edema.
   Labs, meds reviewed. Fluid balance 0.5 L positive.
   IMP: ongoing shock, at this point more likely hypovolemic given 4 days
   of appropriate antibiotic coverage and high urine output/low CVP
   yesterday, possibly adrenal insufficiency.
   Will continue to hydrate with IVF (keeping up with urine losses if
   possible), add HC 50 mg q6h. If hypotension persists, consider adding
   to Vasopressin. Remains on Vanc/Zosyn. Respiratory status acceptable
   with good sats but watch for volume overload.
   ID
s input appreciated. Will likely require 6 week course of
   Ceftriaxone /Flagyl once discharged. He will also eventually need to be
   reassessed for skin flap.
   Rest of the plan as outlined above in Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 7173**]
s note.
   Patient is critically ill. Total time 33 minutes. Full code.

s input appreciated. Will likely require 6 week course of
